isis.stitle: REPAIR INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIBERGLASS AND PLASTIC (ABS) MATERIAL - FIBERGLASS - SURFACE FILLING AND FINISHING

svcproc.title: SURFACE FILLING AND FINISHING

note.para: If you have used screws to align the panel, remove screws and fill the holes with body filler before finishing the panel.

svcproc.para: After repairing the damaged area, apply filler and finish the surface using following procedure:

step1.para: Following the manufacturer's instructions, mix enough body filler to re-establish the surface.

caution.para: Mix filler on formica, teflon or other hard surface. Do not work on a porous surface such as cardboard.

step1.para: Work the filler into the repaired surface with a squeegee, making sure to fill all voids and remove large air bubbles ( Figure 50).

figure.caption: Figure 50. Work Filler into Repaired Surface

note.para: Allow filler to extend above the original surface to allow for shrinkage.

step1.para: When the filler is firm to the touch, plane and/or file off the excess, still leaving the filler level slightly above that of the original surface ( Figure 51).

figure.caption: Figure 51. Plane and/or File Off Excess Filler

step1.para: Now, pre-shrink the filler, using a heat gun or heat lamp. A minimum temperature of 120°F (49°C) is required for shrinkage ( Figure 52). Remove heat lamp when repaired area gets very warm, NOT HOT.

warning.para: Keep heat source at least 12 inches ( 305 mm) away from the repair area.

step1.para: Power-sand the filler with 360 grit sandpaper until it is smooth and even with the original surface.

If the filler is slightly porous (has fine pinholes), apply a thin coat of glazing putty ( Figure 53). If the filler is pockmarked, do not use glazing putty. Instead, apply another layer of body filler as covered in Steps 1 through 5 before applying the glazing putty.

figure.caption: Figure 53. Apply Thin Coat of Glazing Putty

step1.para: Allow the glazing putty to cure using a heat lamp, if necessary. Remove heat lamp when repaired area gets warm, NOT HOT. Finish by sanding with a sanding block and 360 grit sandpaper.

Clean the area with air and remask, if necessary. Then spot prime the surface and wet sand with 400 to 600 grit sandpaper. Complete the repair by painting the surface. Refer to GROUP 16 - PAINT section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
